pages:
NIGHT 16

You've made your choice. The Tunnels. The engineering path.

Bastian sleeps below, his breathing slow and steady. The lighthouse beam sweeps past your window every thirty seconds, like clockwork.

You slide down from your bunk, careful not to wake your cellmate. Behind the small table, exactly where you found it two weeks ago, is the loose stone.

You press it gently. It shifts. Someone has definitely been working on this. But who? And when?
The stone is loose enough now that you could remove it completely. But what's behind it? A hiding place? A passage? Or just another dead end?

content.text:
Your heart pounds. This is it. The first step down a path you can't turn back from.

You could remove the stone now. Or you could search the cell more thoroughly first - maybe there are tools hidden somewhere. Or you could wake Bastian. If he's been working on this stone, maybe he's an ally. If not... well, you need to know that too.

choices.text: Remove the loose stone immediately
Search the cell for tools first
Wake Bastian and ask about the stone

pages:
You work the stone carefully, wiggling it back and forth. Years of mortar crumble away. Finally, it comes free in your hands.

Behind it: darkness. A cavity in the wall, about the size of a shoebox. Your engineer's mind immediately calculates - this isn't just a hiding space. This hole goes deeper than it should.

You reach inside carefully. Your fingers touch something. Paper? No - cloth. You pull it out.

A small canvas bundle, wrapped tight and tied with string. Whatever's inside is hard, angular. You unwrap it in the dim light.

A rusted spoon, filed to a sharp edge. A stub of pencil. Three matches wrapped in wax paper. And a folded piece of paper with a crude map drawn on it.

At the bottom of the map, two words: 'THE CATACOMBS'

You search methodically, the way an engineer approaches a problem. Every surface. Every seam. Every possible hiding place.

Under your thin mattress: nothing. Behind the bucket: nothing. Along the windowsill: wait.

A small chip in the concrete. You dig at it with your fingernail. Something's wedged inside. You work it loose.

A thin piece of wire, maybe four inches long. Bent at one end. Someone made this into a lockpick.
You pocket the wire and turn your attention back to the loose stone. Time to see what's behind it.

choices.text: Remove the stone

pages:
You shake Bastian's shoulder gently. He wakes instantly, eyes alert - the survival instinct of a longtime prisoner.

"Alexandre?" he whispers. "What is it?"
You point to the loose stone. Bastian's eyes widen, then narrow. His expression is unreadable in the darkness.

"So. You found it." His voice is carefully neutral. "I wondered if you would. That stone has been loose for years. Three prisoners before you. None of them brave enough - or foolish enough - to actually remove it."
content.speaker: Bastian Laurent

choices.text: "Did you loosen it?"
"What's behind it?"
"Are you going to report me?"

content.text:
Bastian nods slowly. "I did. Years ago, when I first arrived. I was... younger then. More hopeful."

He sits up on his bunk. "Behind that stone is a cache. Tools. A map. Left by a prisoner who died trying to escape through the catacombs beneath this fortress."

"I've kept it hidden. Waiting for someone I could trust. Someone smart enough to make it work." He meets your eyes. "You're an engineer, Alexandre. You might actually have a chance."
content.speaker: Bastian Laurent

choices.text: "Will you come with me?"
"Why didn't you go yourself?"

content.text:
Bastian shakes his head. "I'm too old for crawling through tunnels, my friend. And my escape... it won't be through the catacombs. I have other plans."

He stands and removes the loose stone himself, pulling out the canvas bundle. "But you? You have the skills. The determination. Take these. Use them wisely."

"And Alexandre? When you make it out... expose Marchand. Tell the world what he did. That's all I ask."
content.speaker: Bastian Laurent

content.text:
"Because I'm not an engineer," Bastian says simply. "The map shows the way into the catacombs, but after that? Collapsed passages. Flooded chambers. Structural failures waiting to happen."

"A political philosopher has no business trying to navigate that death trap." He smiles grimly. "But you? You can read a building like I read people. You might actually survive it."
content.speaker: Bastian Laurent

content.text:
"Tools," Bastian says flatly. "And a map to the catacombs. Left by a man who died trying to escape through them."

He watches you carefully. "You're planning to try, aren't you? The tunnel route."

He sighs. "Take the tools if you want. I have no use for them. But know this: three men have tried the catacombs in the last decade. None returned."
content.speaker: Bastian Laurent

choices.text: "I'm willing to take that risk"
"Thank you for the warning"

content.text:
Bastian nods. "Brave. Or foolish. Sometimes it's hard to tell the difference."

He removes the stone and hands you the bundle. "Good luck, engineer. You'll need it."
content.speaker: Bastian Laurent

content.text:
"Smart," Bastian says. "But you're going anyway, aren't you? I can see it in your eyes."

He removes the stone and pulls out the bundle. "Then at least go prepared. Take these. And Alexandre? Be careful."
content.speaker: Bastian Laurent

content.text:
Bastian looks at you for a long moment. "Report you? No, Alexandre. Whatever else I am, I'm not a collaborator."

He gestures to the stone. "Take what's in there if you want it. I won't stop you. I won't help you either. Your escape is your own business."

"Just... don't get me killed in the process."
content.speaker: Bastian Laurent

content.text:
You unwrap the bundle carefully. A sharpened spoon. Matches. A pencil stub. And the map.

You study it by the faint moonlight. The fortress layout. Cell blocks. Guard towers. And beneath it all, marked in fading ink: a network of tunnels.

"The catacombs," Bastian whispers. "Medieval smuggler tunnels that predate the prison by three hundred years. They connect to the old wine cellars, then to a drainage system that runs under the walls."

"If you can navigate them without getting lost, crushed, or drowned... you might just make it to the coast."

pages:
You stare at the map for a long time. The entrance to the catacombs is marked clearly: the old chapel basement. That's on the other side of the prison yard.

Getting there means crossing open ground. Dodging the lighthouse beam. Timing the guard patrols perfectly. And that's before you even reach the tunnels themselves.
Your engineering mind starts calculating. Distances. Timing. Risk factors. This isn't impossible. Difficult, yes. Dangerous, absolutely. But not impossible.

The Path of the Tunnels stretches before you. Lonely. Technical. Methodical.

Exactly as you chose.

You carefully hide the tools under your mattress and climb back into your bunk. Tomorrow, you'll begin reconnaissance of the chapel. Tomorrow, the real work begins.

But tonight, for the first time since you were convicted, you feel something you thought you'd lost forever:

Hope.

NIGHT 20 - THE CHAPEL

Four nights of observation. Four nights of timing the lighthouse, counting guard rotations, mapping the yard in your mind.

Now: the moment of truth.
You slip out of your cell during the seventeen-minute gap. The corridor is empty. Your heart hammers as you move through shadows, timing each step to the rhythm you've memorized.

The chapel looms ahead. Gothic stone, older than the prison itself. The basement entrance is around the back - a heavy wooden door with a rusted padlock.

This is where your lockpick earns its keep.

content.text:
The basement door creaks open. Below: total darkness. A stone staircase descending into blackness.

You have three matches. Three precious sources of light. Once they're gone, you'll be navigating by touch alone.

Or you could try descending in darkness now, saving your matches for when you truly need them. The stairs are stone - you can feel your way down. Probably.

choices.text: Light a match and descend safely (-1 match)
Descend in darkness, save the matches

pages:
You strike the match. Sulfur flares. Sudden orange light reveals a narrow staircase - twenty steps down into a stone basement.

The match illuminates everything: wine racks (empty for decades), moldering crates, a collapsed section of ceiling. And there, at the far end: a hole in the wall where the stones have fallen away.

You memorize the layout before the match burns your fingers. You drop it, stamp it out.

Darkness returns. But you know the way now. Straight ahead, fifteen paces, slight left turn.

You descend in blackness. One hand on the cold stone wall. Feet feeling for each step.

Thirteen steps. Fourteen. Your foot finds empty air - you stumble, catch yourself. That could have been bad.

Finally: solid ground. You're in the basement. But where exactly? You know the entrance to the catacombs is somewhere ahead, but in this absolute darkness, you'll have to search by touch.

Unless you light a match now.

content.text:
You navigate by memory in the darkness. Fifteen paces. Turn left. Your hands find the broken stones.

Beyond this wall lie the catacombs. Medieval smuggler tunnels that haven't seen light in centuries.

You have two matches left. You'll need them.

You squeeze through the gap in the wall and into the unknown.

You're in total darkness. The basement is maybe thirty paces across, but you don't know which direction leads to the catacombs entrance.

You could search blindly - feeling along walls, hoping to find the gap in the stones. It might take precious minutes, and you might knock something over, make noise.

Or you could light a match. Get your bearings. But that's another match gone.

choices.text: Light a match to find the entrance (-1 match)
Search blindly in the dark

content.text:
Another match. Another precious second of light.

The basement reveals itself: you're only three paces from the catacombs entrance. You were closer than you thought.

The match dies. You move quickly through the gap while the afterimage still burns in your eyes.

pages: You feel your way through the darkness. Left wall. Follow it. Your hands touch rotting wood, cold stone, something that crumbles to dust.

Minutes pass. How many? Five? Ten? You're losing track of time.

Then: a gap. Cool air flowing through. This is it.

You squeeze through into an even deeper darkness. The catacombs.

You've conserved your matches, but the journey took longer than it should have. Somewhere above, a guard might be making his rounds. Might notice your cell door isn't quite latched.

No time to worry about that now. You're committed.

content.text:
The catacombs.

The air is cold and damp. Water drips somewhere in the darkness. The silence is absolute - no guards, no prisoners, no lighthouse beam. Just you and the ancient stone.

You pull out the map. In the darkness, it's useless. You'll need light to read it. Or you could try to navigate by feel, following the left wall.

You need to make a decision. The map shows the route, but reading it means using a match. Or you could trust your engineer's instincts and navigate blind.

How many matches do you have left? You try to remember. Did you use one? Two? The darkness makes it hard to think clearly.

choices.text: Light a match and check the map (-1 match)
Navigate blind, follow the left wall

content.text:
Match flare. The map comes into focus.

You're at the entrance. The main passage runs straight for about fifty meters, then splits. Left leads to the old wine cellars (collapsed). Right leads deeper into the smuggler tunnels toward the drainage system.

Right is the way. You memorize the route before the match dies.

You press your left hand against the cold stone wall and start walking. Slow. Careful. Counting your paces.

Fifteen. Twenty. Thirty. The passage seems straight. Your engineering mind tries to build a mental map, but without visual reference points, it's guesswork.

Forty paces. Fifty. The wall curves slightly. Or does it? In absolute darkness, even your sense of direction becomes unreliable.

pages: You move through the darkness with purpose. Fifty paces straight. The passage is narrow - barely shoulder-width. Your hands brush both walls.
Sixty paces. Seventy. Your foot touches something - debris. You step carefully over it. The map showed this passage was mostly intact, but 'mostly' isn't the same as 'completely.'
Eighty paces. The passage widens slightly. You should be approaching the junction soon.

Sixty paces. Seventy. Your foot catches on something in the darkness - a fallen stone, a piece of timber. You stumble but catch yourself.

Your hand scrapes against rough stone. Sharp pain. You feel warm blood. Not serious, but it stings.

Eighty paces. Ninety. You're not sure if you're still going straight. The left wall technique works in theory, but in practice, in absolute darkness, every irregularity in the wall makes you second-guess.

You hear something. Water. Distant, but definitely water. Dripping? Flowing? You can't tell. But water means the drainage system is nearby. Or it means you're approaching a flooded section.

Both possibilities exist on the map.

content.text:
The junction.

Your hands find the opening - the passage splits here. Left or right. In the darkness, they feel identical. Cold stone, damp air, absolute silence.

The map showed this junction clearly. The right path leads toward the old drainage system and eventually to the catacombs' outer wall. The left path circles back into the prison's foundation - a dead end.

But knowing the map and following it in total darkness are different things.

choices.text: Take the right passage (toward freedom)
Take the left passage
Use a match to check the map one more time (-1 match)

content.text:
One more match. Your last one.

Sulfur flares. Orange light floods the junction. The map confirms it - right leads to the drainage system, left curves back.

But the brief light reveals something else: ancient markings on the right passage wall. Scratches. Arrows pointing forward. Someone else found this route. Long ago.

You take the right passage. The air grows colder, damper. You can hear water now - not dripping, but flowing. A stream or drainage channel somewhere ahead.

The passage slopes downward. Your feet splash through shallow puddles. The ancient stones beneath are slick with moisture and algae.

Then: another junction. You feel it with your hands - the passage splits three ways. Three different routes forward.

THREE PASSAGES.

Left passage: Dry air. Smells of dust and old stone. Narrow opening.

Center passage: The sound of water is loudest here. Cool, damp air rushing past. Wide enough to walk upright.

Right passage: Warmer air. Odd smell - not unpleasant, but strange. Organic. The passage feels larger.

You need to scout these routes before committing. But scouting in total darkness means risk.

choices.text: Scout the left passage (dry, narrow)
Scout the center passage (water sounds)
Scout the right passage (warm, strange smell)

content.text:
You squeeze into the left passage. It's tight - shoulder-width at best. The walls press close on both sides.

Twenty paces in, it gets tighter. You have to turn sideways. Thirty paces, and you can barely fit. Your chest scrapes one wall, your back against the other.

Forty paces. You can't go further without getting stuck. And you feel something under your fingers - a crack in the wall. Wide enough to get your hand through. Empty space beyond.

A branching tunnel? A cavity? You can't tell in the darkness. But this passage is too narrow. Not viable for escape.

You follow the sound of water into the center passage. The air is cold and damp. The walls are slick with moisture.

Ten paces. Twenty. The water sound grows louder. Your foot touches something - you kneel and feel.

A channel cut into the floor. Water flowing through it. Fast-moving. Cold as ice. This is the drainage system - exactly what the map showed.

You follow the channel for thirty more paces. The passage is stable, well-constructed. This route leads somewhere. But the water is rising. It's already ankle-deep in places.

A rainstorm above ground would flood this tunnel completely.

You enter the right passage. It's warmer here. The strange organic smell is stronger.

Ten paces. Twenty. Your foot touches something soft. You kneel and feel - vegetation? Moss? Something growing down here in the dark.

Thirty paces. The passage opens into what feels like a larger space. A chamber or cavern. You can't feel walls on either side. The air moves differently here.

Then: a sound. Soft. Rhythmic.

Breathing.

Something else is down here with you.

The breathing is slow. Heavy. Not human.

You freeze. Your engineer's mind races - what could survive down here? Rats, certainly. Bats, maybe. But this sounds larger.

The breathing continues. Whatever it is, it hasn't noticed you. Or it's waiting.

choices.text: Back away slowly and quietly
Make noise to scare it away
Move forward cautiously to investigate

content.text:
You shout. Your voice echoes in the chamber.

IMMEDIATE RESPONSE.

Scrabbling claws on stone. Multiple creatures - not one, but several. They scatter, fleeing deeper into the chamber with squeals and hisses.

Rats. Large ones, from the sound. Maybe feral dogs that found their way into the catacombs years ago. Either way, they're gone now.

Your heart hammers. But the passage is clear. And you found something else - in the brief chaos, you felt a wooden crate against the wall. Supplies? Left by smugglers?

You move forward, one careful step at a time. Your hands outstretched.

The breathing stops.

Silence.

Then: movement. Fast. Something rushes past you in the darkness - fur brushing your leg. Claws skittering on stone.

Rats. Or possibly feral cats. Whatever they are, they're fleeing from you now. You're the intruder in their domain.

Your foot touches something - you kneel and feel. A wooden crate. Old, rotting, but still intact. Inside: glass bottles. Most broken. But one remains whole.

You explore the chamber carefully. It's large - maybe ten meters across. The walls are natural rock, not cut stone. This was a natural cavern that the smugglers incorporated into their tunnel system.

Besides the crate, you find: rotted rope, rusted metal hooks, and what feels like an old oil lantern (no oil, unfortunately).

This chamber connects to another passage on the far side. The air flowing through smells fresher. This route might lead outside.

But the creatures could return. And you'd be navigating through their territory.

You return to the three-way junction. Your scouting is complete.

Left passage: Too narrow. Dead end or branches into unknown smaller tunnels.

Center passage: The drainage system. Stable, well-constructed, but flood risk is high. If it rains above ground, you'd drown.

Right passage: Natural cavern system. Creatures living there, but they can be scared off. Appears to have an exit route. Risky but potentially the best option.

You need to choose. And choose now. You've been down here for... how long? An hour? Two? The guards will notice your absence eventually.

DECISION POINT.

Which route will you take?

The drainage system (center) is the most direct route to the outer walls. But the water level is concerning.

The cavern system (right) is dangerous and unpredictable, but you found supplies and detected fresher air from the far passage.

Or... you could try to squeeze through the narrow left passage and see where that crack in the wall leads. Risky, claustrophobic, but unexplored.

choices.text: Take the drainage system route (center) - direct but flood risk
Take the cavern system route (right) - dangerous but promising
Risk the narrow passage (left) - explore the crack in the wall

content.text:
You commit to the drainage route.

The water is ankle-deep when you enter. Cold. Fast-moving. You follow the channel carved into the floor, using it as a guide in the darkness.

Fifty paces. The passage is stable. Well-constructed by engineers who knew their craft.

Seventy paces. The water rises to your shins. You're descending deeper.

One hundred paces. Knee-deep now. The current is stronger. You have to brace yourself against the walls to avoid being swept off your feet.

You commit to the cavern route.

Back through the right passage. Into the chamber. The creatures are gone - or hiding. You can't hear breathing anymore.

You navigate by touch to the far side where you detected the fresher air. Your hands find the continuation: a passage carved through natural rock. Rougher than the constructed tunnels, but wide and stable.

The air is definitely fresher here. You can smell... earth. Trees? Impossible. You're underground. But the scent is unmistakable.

You return to the narrow left passage.

Squeeze sideways. Twenty paces. Thirty. The walls press against your chest and back. Forty paces - you reach the crack.

You feel through it. Empty space beyond. Cool air flowing through.

You work at the crack, pulling loose stones. Your fingers bleed. Five minutes of work. Ten. The opening widens.

Finally: large enough to squeeze through. Barely.

You push yourself into the crack. For a terrible moment, you're stuck - trapped between walls of ancient stone. Then: you force yourself through and tumble into the space beyond.

The water reaches your waist.

You're committed now. Turning back means fighting against the current. Forward is the only option.

One hundred twenty paces. The passage levels out. The water stays waist-deep but stops rising.

Then you hear it: a roaring sound ahead. Louder than the current. Something big. A waterfall? An outlet?

You push forward through the cold water. The roaring grows deafening.

The natural passage winds upward. You're ascending now - a good sign. The smell of earth grows stronger.

Your hands find tree roots pushing through the ceiling. Small ones at first, then thicker. The passage is being invaded by the forest above.

You navigate around them. Thirty paces. Fifty. The air is definitely fresher. You can feel temperature changes - warmer air mixing with the cold underground draft.

Then: a sound. Not creatures. Not water.

Voices.

You're in a different tunnel system. Older. Much older.

The walls are rough-hewn stone. Medieval, perhaps earlier. This isn't part of the prison's foundation - this is something ancient that existed long before ÃŽle de Pierre became a fortress.

You follow the passage. It's narrow but navigable. Fifty paces. One hundred. The air is stale. No one has been here in centuries.

Your foot touches something - you kneel and feel. Bones.

Human bones.

A skeleton, still wearing the remnants of old clothing. How long has this person been here? Who were they?

Light.

Gray. Faint. But unmistakably light.

The drainage channel empties through a grate into the ocean. You can see it now - moonlight filtering through iron bars. The Atlantic crashing against rocks below.

You've reached the outer wall of the prison island. The exit is right here. Ten meters of tunnel and a grate separating you from freedom.

But the grate is solid iron. Three inches thick. Locked from the outside. You can't break through it without tools.

The voices are above you. You're directly beneath... the prison yard? No. The tone is different. Casual conversation. Laughter.

A guard station. Or the barracks.

You freeze. Moving forward risks making noise. They might hear you through the stone. But you can't go back now.

You wait. Five minutes. Ten. The voices fade - they've moved away.

You continue forward carefully. The passage ends at a vertical shaft. Looking up, you can see a faint square of moonlight. A trapdoor? A ventilation grate?

This route leads up into the prison complex. Not to freedom, but to a different part of the fortress. That might be useful... or deadly.

You search the skeleton carefully. Old clothing - 17th century, maybe. A leather pouch at the belt.

Inside the pouch: a key. Iron. Ancient but intact.

A key to what?

You continue past the skeleton. The tunnel slopes upward. After another hundred paces, you find: a door.

Wooden. Reinforced with iron bands. Very old but remarkably preserved in the dry tunnel air.

The key fits the lock. It turns with a grinding sound.

The door opens.

You've scouted the catacombs. You've found routes. You've discovered secrets.

But this is just reconnaissance. You need to return to your cell before the guards notice your absence. This escape will take planning. Multiple trips. Tools. Preparation.

You've learned the layout. Now you need to decide: which route will be your path to freedom?

You begin the long journey back through the darkness toward the chapel basement.

The return journey is easier. You know the way now. Through the catacombs, through the basement, through the chapel.

You emerge into the prison yard during the seventeen-minute gap. The lighthouse beam sweeps past. You slip through shadows, back to your cell block.

Bastian is awake when you return. He says nothing, but his eyes ask questions.

You don't answer. Not yet.

NIGHT 25 - FIVE NIGHTS LATER

You've spent every moment planning. The route is clear in your mind. But you need tools. Equipment. Resources.

The grate at the drainage outlet is iron. Three inches thick. You'll need cutting tools - a hacksaw at minimum, ideally a file and metal shears.

Or you could focus on the ancient tunnels. That door you unlocked leads somewhere. But navigating without light is suicide. You need a reliable light source.

Or the vertical shaft under the guard barracks. That trapdoor could give you access to areas of the prison you've never seen. But it's the riskiest route.

Three routes. Three different preparations needed.

DRAINAGE ROUTE: Need cutting tools for the grate. The prison kitchen has equipment. Dangerous to steal, but possible.

ANCIENT TUNNEL ROUTE: Need reliable light and supplies. That smuggler's cache might have more. Or you could barter in the prison black market.

VERTICAL SHAFT ROUTE: Need intel on what's above. Guard schedules. Room layouts. A way to blend in if discovered.

Which route will you commit to?

choices.text: Commit to the drainage route - steal tools from the kitchen
Commit to the ancient tunnel route - gather supplies
Commit to the vertical shaft route - gather intelligence

content.text:
The drainage route. Direct. Engineering-focused. Exactly your skillset.

The grate is the only obstacle. Get through it, and you're in the Atlantic. A strong swimmer could make it to the mainland. Or at least to the fishing routes where you could signal a boat.

But first: tools.

The prison kitchen. You've never worked there, but you've observed it during meals. Industrial equipment. Meat saws. Cleavers. Exactly what you need.

The ancient tunnel route. Mysterious. Unknown. Full of potential.

That door opened to... what? You didn't explore beyond it during your scouting. The skeleton suggests someone tried this route centuries ago and failed.

But you're an engineer. You have advantages they didn't. Maps. Planning. Knowledge.

You need supplies. Rope, definitely. Food and water for potentially days underground. And light - multiple light sources.

The vertical shaft route. Bold. Insane, perhaps.

That shaft leads directly into the prison complex. Not to freedom - to danger. But what if you could access areas prisoners never see? The warden's office. The guard armory. Files. Evidence.

This isn't just about escaping. This is about understanding the prison's secrets. About finding proof of Marchand's conspiracy.

But you need information first. Guard schedules. Room layouts. What's at the top of that shaft.

You approach Bastian the next morning.

"I need to get assigned to kitchen duty," you tell him quietly.

He doesn't ask why. He just nods. "Ã‰mile Beaumont controls work assignments. Everything in this prison goes through him. You'll need to pay."

"With what?"

Bastian smiles grimly. "Everyone has something to trade. Information. Favors. Skills. What can you offer an organization run by criminals?"

An engineer's expertise. Your ability to fix things, build things, understand complex systems.

You're about to make a deal with the prison's most dangerous man.

The smuggler's cache in the cavern. That's where you start.

You return to the catacombs that night. Through the chapel, through the basement, through the darkness you're beginning to know like the back of your hand.

The chamber with the creatures. They scatter when you enter - they've learned you're not prey.

The wooden crate. You search it thoroughly this time. Besides the glass bottle and lantern, you find:

Rotted rope (useless). A rusted knife (corroded but maybe salvageable). And underneath everything: a leather-wrapped bundle.

You unwrap it. Inside: oil. Lamp oil. Still liquid after decades in the sealed container.

Your lantern has fuel.

You need information. And in prison, information flows through one source: the black market.

Ã‰mile Beaumont's network knows everything. Guard schedules. Room layouts. Contraband. Secrets.

But approaching Ã‰mile directly is dangerous. You're nobody. A new prisoner. Why would he talk to you?

Unless you have something he wants.

You think about your engineering skills. Your ability to understand complex systems. The prison's infrastructure - electrical, plumbing, structural.

What if you could offer him something valuable? Access to areas he can't reach? Information about the prison's vulnerabilities?

It's risky. But this entire escape is risky.

NIGHT 27

Seven nights since you committed to the drainage route. Seven nights of planning. Seven nights of working with Ã‰mile Beaumont to secure your kitchen duty assignment.

The cost? Information. Intelligence about the guard rotations. A mental map of the prison's blind spots. Things Ã‰mile could use for his own schemes.

But tonight, it's worth it. You're assigned to kitchen cleanup duty - the late shift, after the dinner service ends. The perfect cover to steal the tools you need: a sturdy knife, waterproof cloth, maybe some rope if you're lucky.

Chef Pierre Dubois runs the kitchen like a military operation. Nothing goes missing. Nothing gets wasted. If you're caught stealing, you won't just lose kitchen privileges - you'll lose Ã‰mile's trust, and possibly your only route to freedom.

content.text:
The kitchen is massive - industrial ovens, stainless steel counters, rows of hanging pots and pans. The smell of tonight's stew still lingers in the air: watery vegetables and mystery meat.

Chef Pierre stands at the far end, reviewing tomorrow's menu with his assistant. Two other inmates scrub pots at the washing station. A guard leans against the doorway, bored, checking his watch every thirty seconds.

You've been assigned to the prep station - cleaning cutting boards, organizing utensils, wiping down surfaces. Simple work. Mindless work. The perfect cover.

You survey your options:

The knife rack is directly in Chef Pierre's line of sight, but he's distracted with paperwork. The utility closet near the loading dock has rope and cloth - but the guard watches that area intermittently. The washing station has the other inmates, but they're focused on their work.

You need to time this perfectly. One mistake, and everything falls apart.

choices.text: Study the guard's patrol pattern first - be methodical
Create a distraction and grab what you need - be bold

pages:
You work slowly, deliberately, watching the guard out of the corner of your eye.

Every 90 seconds, he walks to the loading dock entrance and peers outside. Checks his watch. Returns to his post. Every third rotation, he stops at the water cooler for a drink - that's when his back is fully turned.

Chef Pierre, meanwhile, follows a different rhythm. He inspects the ovens every ten minutes, reviews inventory every twenty, and steps into his office - a small glass-walled room overlooking the kitchen - periodically to make phone calls.

The other two inmates are predictable: one washes, one rinses, they rotate every few minutes. Neither pays attention to anything but their task. Good workers. Complacent workers.

You've identified a 45-second window: when the guard is at the water cooler AND Chef Pierre is in his office making a call. It'll happen in approximately six minutes.

Six minutes to prepare. Six minutes to position yourself. Six minutes to decide exactly what you're going for.

The knife? The rope? The cloth? You probably only have time to grab one thing safely. Two if you're fast. All three if you're reckless.

Sometimes the best plan is chaos.

You 'accidentally' knock over a tray of utensils near the washing station. The clatter echoes through the kitchen - forks, spoons, knives scattering across the tile floor.

The guard's head snaps up. Chef Pierre turns from his paperwork. The two inmates at the washing station jump back, startled.

"Merde!" Chef Pierre barks, striding toward you. "What kind of amateurâ€”"

"Sorry, Chef," you say quickly, dropping to your knees to gather the scattered utensils. "My hand slipped."

The guard takes a step forward, then stops - this isn't worth his attention. Just another clumsy inmate. He returns to his post.

Chef Pierre looms over you, scowling. "Clean this up. Now. And if you drop anything else tonight, you're done in my kitchen. Compris?"

But while everyone's attention was on the fallen utensils, you had a brief moment - maybe three, four seconds - where no one was watching your hands.

Did you grab something? Could you have palmed a small knife, stuffed a cloth into your waistband, pocketed something from the scattered pile?

You're still on the floor, gathering utensils, Chef Pierre glaring down at you. Whatever you grabbed - if you grabbed anything - it's done now. No going back.

content.text:
You approach the washing station casually, carrying a stack of cutting boards.

"Need any help?" you ask the nearest inmate - a wiry man with nervous eyes named Carlos.

He glances at you, suspicious. "We're fine."

"I'm just saying," you continue, setting down the boards, "if you ever needed someone to, I don't know, keep Chef Pierre distracted for a minute, I could probably manage that."

Carlos's hands stop moving. The other inmate - a heavyset man called TomÃ¡s - looks over.

"Why would we need that?" TomÃ¡s asks quietly.

You shrug. "No reason. Just thinking out loud."

The window is approaching. The guard heads for the water cooler. Chef Pierre's phone rings - he steps into his office.

Now.

You move toward your target. Your heart pounds. Every second counts.

choices.text: Grab the knife - essential for the drainage grate
Grab the waterproof cloth - essential for the flooded passages
Grab the rope - useful for climbing
Be greedy - grab the knife AND the cloth (risky)

content.text:
You stand up, utensils gathered, Chef Pierre still watching you with suspicion.

Did you manage to grab anything during the distraction? Your hand moved so fast, you're not even sure yourself. But you feel... something. A weight in your pocket. A bulge in your waistband.

Chef Pierre is still staring at you. If you did grab something, and he searches you now, it's over.

choices.text: You grabbed a small paring knife during the chaos
You grabbed a folded cloth during the chaos
You didn't grab anything - too risky with Chef Pierre watching

pages:
There's a long silence. Then Carlos speaks, barely above a whisper:

"Tomorrow night. Same shift. We need a five-minute distraction."

"What for?" you ask.

TomÃ¡s shakes his head. "Don't ask questions. Just... if you can do it, we can make sure you get what you came here for."

He gestures subtly toward the utility closet. He knows. They both know. You're not the first person to try to steal from Chef Pierre's kitchen.

"I can do it," you say. "But I need something tonight. Just one item. Something small."

Carlos and TomÃ¡s exchange a glance. Then Carlos nods slowly.

"Finish your work. When the guard does his loading dock check in ten minutes, we'll cover you. One item. That's all."

You nod. An alliance formed in whispers over a washing station. In El Palo de Queso, this is how trust is built - not through words, but through mutually assured risk.

content.text:
You slide the knife from the rack - a sturdy chef's knife, eight inches long, sharp as a promise. It disappears into your waistband, hidden under your shirt.

30 seconds left.

You return to the prep station, force yourself to breathe normally. The guard returns from the water cooler. Chef Pierre steps out of his office.

Neither of them noticed. The knife presses cold against your skin. Success.

You move to the utility closet, grab a folded square of waterproof canvas - the kind used for covering supplies on the loading dock. It's compact, durable, perfect for protecting items in the flooded drainage tunnels.

You stuff it inside your shirt, flatten it against your chest.

25 seconds left.

Back to the prep station. Breathe. Act natural. The guard returns. Chef Pierre emerges from his office.

You did it. The cloth is hidden. No one saw.

The rope hangs on a hook near the loading dock - twenty feet of sturdy hemp, used for securing supply crates. You coil it quickly, stuff it under your shirt.

It's bulky. Obvious. If anyone looks at you closely, they'll see the bulge.

20 seconds left.

You hurry back to the prep station, trying to position yourself so the rope's bulk isn't visible. The guard returns. Chef Pierre steps out of his office.

Your shirt looks strange. Lumpy. But no one's looking directly at you. Not yet.

pages:
Greedy. You're being greedy. But you need both.

Knife first - into the waistband. Then the cloth - stuffed inside your shirt. Your movements are fast, practiced, but the window is closing.

15 seconds left.

You turn back toward the prep station. The guard is still at the water cooler, but he's finishing his drink. Chef Pierre is ending his call.

10 seconds.

You're halfway across the kitchen when it happens:

The knife shifts. The blade - you forgot to position it correctly - presses against your belt, and the handle protrudes slightly above your waistband.

5 seconds.

Chef Pierre steps out of his office. His eyes sweep the kitchen - and stop. On you.

He saw something. Maybe just a flicker of movement. Maybe the knife handle. You can't be sure.

content.text:
The paring knife is small - four inches, easy to conceal. During the chaos of the dropped utensils, you palmed it and slipped it into your sock.

Chef Pierre finally stops glaring at you. "Get back to work," he mutters, returning to his paperwork.

The guard has already lost interest. The other inmates have returned to washing.

You finish gathering the utensils, heart pounding. The knife presses against your ankle. Small, but sharp. It'll have to be enough.

The cloth was folded near the scattered utensils - a small kitchen towel, absorbent and durable. Not waterproof canvas, but it'll help.

You stuffed it into your waistband while everyone was focused on the fallen silverware.

Chef Pierre dismisses you with a wave. "Back to work. And be more careful."

The guard yawns. The inmates return to their tasks.

You stand up, the cloth hidden beneath your shirt. Not perfect, but better than nothing.

You didn't grab anything. Too risky. Chef Pierre was watching too closely, and getting caught would've meant losing everything - the kitchen access, Ã‰mile's trust, the entire plan.

Sometimes the smart play is the patient play.

Chef Pierre eventually turns back to his paperwork. The guard returns to his post. The kitchen settles back into routine.

You'll have to try again. Find another opportunity. Another window.

Ten minutes later, right on schedule, the guard steps through the loading dock door for his routine check outside.

Carlos and TomÃ¡s immediately start a loud conversation about tomorrow's menu, drawing Chef Pierre's attention to the washing station.

You have maybe 90 seconds. One item. Choose wisely.

content.text:
The rest of the shift passes without incident. You clean, organize, follow Chef Pierre's barked instructions. The stolen item stays hidden - pressed against your skin, tucked in your clothes, concealed in the folds of your uniform.

When the shift ends, you file out with the other inmates. The guard does a cursory pat-down at the kitchen exit, but it's perfunctory - he's tired, ready for his shift to end. He doesn't feel the knife in your waistband, doesn't notice the cloth under your shirt, doesn't check your socks.

You're through. Back into the main cell block. The item is yours.

Chef Pierre walks toward you. His eyes are sharp, calculating.

"You," he says, voice low. "Come here."

Your heart hammers. The knife is hidden, but barely. The cloth creates a subtle bulge. If he searches you, if he pats you down, it's over.

The guard watches with mild interest. The other inmates have stopped working, sensing drama.

content.text:
The shift ends empty-handed. You return to your cell with nothing to show for the risk you took - or rather, the risk you didn't take.

Bastian is awake when you arrive, sitting on his bunk.

"How was kitchen duty?" he asks.

You shrug. "Uneventful."

He studies you for a moment, then nods. "There's always tomorrow night."

He's right. You still have kitchen access. You can try again. But time is running out, and Ã‰mile won't wait forever for results.

pages:
Back in your cell, you hide your prize in the small cache behind the loose stone. The same cache where you found the map of the catacombs. The same cache that's been waiting for someone - anyone - brave enough to use it.

Bastian is asleep. He doesn't know what you've done tonight. Maybe that's better. The fewer people who know, the safer you are.

You've taken your first real step toward the drainage route escape. The tools are acquired. The path is clear.

But you can't help thinking about Chef Pierre's kitchen - the precision, the discipline, the way he runs his operation. And you think about Carlos and TomÃ¡s, if you worked with them. Inmates helping inmates. A rare thing in El Palo de Queso.

Maybe there's more than one way to survive this place. Maybe there's more than one kind of escape.

content.text:
"Is something wrong, Chef?" you ask, your voice steady despite the panic rising in your chest.

Chef Pierre stops a few feet away. His eyes scan your face, your posture, looking for tells.

"I thought I saw..." He pauses. "Never mind. Get back to work."

He turns away, returning to his office. Was it your tone? Your expression? Or did he simply decide you weren't worth the trouble?

You'll never know. But you're safe. The items are still hidden. You survived.

Before Chef Pierre reaches you, you 'accidentally' stumble into the prep counter, sending a stack of plates sliding toward the edge.

You catch them - barely - and the guard actually applauds sarcastically.

"Bravo," he says. "Very graceful."

Chef Pierre stops, sighs heavily, and waves you away. "Just... finish your work without breaking anything else."

The distraction worked. Your heart is pounding, but the stolen items remain hidden. You're safe. For now.

You can't risk it. Not with Chef Pierre staring at you like that.

You let the knife slip from your waistband, catch it, and pretend you were just adjusting your shirt. The cloth falls to the floor.

"I was just... cleaning up," you say lamely, holding up the cloth.

Chef Pierre's eyes narrow, but he can't prove anything. You technically didn't steal - you just picked up items and then put them down.

"Back. To. Work," he says, each word clipped.

You nod, returning to the prep station empty-handed. Failure. But at least you're not in solitary.

NIGHT 28

The drainage route plan continues. You have your tools - or you're planning your next attempt. Either way, the path forward is clear.

The flooded tunnels beneath the prison await. The ocean grate is out there, somewhere in the darkness, waiting to be opened.

But first, you need to prepare. Study the guard rotations. Test your tools. Make sure everything is ready.

Because once you enter those tunnels for real - not just for scouting, but for escape - there's no turning back.

pages:
NIGHT 32

Four nights of preparation. Four nights of memorizing the guard schedules, testing your stolen tools, making sure everything is ready.
Tonight is the night. The chapel will be empty. The guard rotation creates a twelve-minute window. The drainage tunnels are waiting.

Bastian is asleep. He doesn't know. He can't know. If this fails, if you're caught, you need him to have deniability.

You slip down from your bunk, silent as a shadow. The loose stone behind the table comes free easily now. Behind it: your cache. Your map. Your tools.

Time to go.
The chapel basement is exactly as you remember it. Dark. Cold. The stairs descending into blackness.
But this time, you're prepared. You have your knife. Your waterproof cloth. Your determination.

The darkness swallows you as you descend. Your hand trails along the stone wall, counting steps. Fifteen. Twenty. Twenty-five.

At the bottom, you pause. Listen.

Water. Dripping. Echoing. And something else - a faint sound, like wind through distant passages.

content.text:
You navigate by memory now. The catacombs are familiar - you've scouted them before. Right at the first junction. Straight through the ossuary. Left at the carved angel.

But as you move deeper, you notice something new.

Marks on the walls. Scratched symbols. Not random - deliberate. Arrows. Crosses. A series of three vertical lines.

Smuggler signs. Someone else has used these tunnels. Recently, judging by how fresh the markings look.

You reach the three-way junction where you chose the drainage route during your scouting mission. The symbols continue down the center passage - the one leading to the flooded drainage system.

The arrows point forward. Toward the ocean grate. Toward freedom.

But the crosses... crosses usually mean danger. Warning. And those three vertical lines appear repeatedly, always before the crosses.

What do they mean? Water levels? Time markers? Smuggler codes you don't understand?

choices.text: Follow the smuggler signs - they know these tunnels
Ignore the signs - stick to your own route
Study the signs more carefully before deciding

content.text:
You follow the arrows. The smugglers know these tunnels better than you ever could. If they marked this route, there's a reason.

The passage slopes downward. The sound of water grows louder. Your feet splash through shallow puddles, then deeper water - ankle-deep, then knee-deep.

The arrows continue, scratched at regular intervals. And then you see it:

A different symbol. A circle with a line through it. Scratched large and deep into the stone, impossible to miss.

And beyond it, the tunnel is completely flooded. Dark water, still and silent, disappearing into the blackness ahead.

You ignore the symbols. They're smuggler codes - useful for criminals running contraband, but you're an engineer. You trust your own observations, your own maps.

You take the route you scouted before. The drainage tunnel angles downward, water trickling along the channel you remember.

But something's different. The water is higher than before. Much higher. What was a trickle is now a steady flow.

And as you wade deeper, the flow becomes a current. The water rises from your ankles to your knees to your waist.

You're in trouble.

pages:
You stop. Study the symbols carefully. Think like an engineer.

Three vertical lines. They appear before every cross. Before every warning.

Three lines. Three... hours? Three feet? Three...

Wait.

You look at the water in the drainage channel. It's flowing. Steady. But the level is marked on the walls - you can see the stains, the mineral deposits showing where the water reaches at different times.

Tidal. The drainage system is tidal. It connects to the ocean, which means it rises and falls with the tide.

Three vertical lines. High tide. The smugglers are warning that this route floods completely at high tide.

And based on the current water level... high tide is coming. Soon.

content.text:
The water is chest-deep now. Cold. The current pulls at your legs, trying to sweep you off your feet.

You can see the drainage outlet ahead - maybe fifty meters. The ocean grate is there, waiting. But the water is rising. Fast.

You have your waterproof cloth. You can protect your tools, your map. But can you make it through before the tunnel floods completely?

choices.text: Push forward - you're almost there
Push forward - risk it even without protection
Turn back - this is suicide

content.text:
You understand now. The drainage route is passable, but only at low tide. You have maybe thirty minutes before high tide floods these tunnels completely.

Thirty minutes to reach the ocean grate. Thirty minutes to cut through it or pry it open. Thirty minutes to escape.

Or you could wait. Find shelter in one of the side chambers. Let high tide pass, then navigate the route at low tide when it's safer.

But waiting means spending hours down here. Hours when the guards might discover you're missing. Hours when your window of opportunity could close.

choices.text: Race against the tide - you have thirty minutes
Wait for low tide - take the safe approach
Look for an alternative route - avoid the drainage entirely

pages:
You wrap your tools and map in the waterproof cloth, seal it tight, and wade forward. The current is strong, but you're stronger.

The water rises to your shoulders. Your neck. You're swimming now, one hand holding the waterproof bundle above your head, the other pulling yourself along the tunnel wall.

The ceiling drops lower. Only inches of air space left. Your lungs burn. The current pulls harder.

And then - light. Faint. Grey. Moonlight filtering through the ocean grate ahead.

You surge forward with your last strength. Your head breaks the surface in a small air pocket at the grate. You made it. Barely.

But now comes the hard part: getting through.

You push forward without protection. The water rises. Your tools are in your pockets, your map clutched in your hand.

Chest-deep. Shoulder-deep. The map dissolves in your fingers, ink bleeding away into the dark water. Your first mistake.

The current strengthens. You're swimming now, fighting to keep your head above water. The tunnel ceiling drops. Inches of air left.

Your knife slips from your pocket. Gone. Your second mistake.

You reach the grate with nothing but your determination and your failing strength. The moonlight filtering through the iron bars mocks you.

You're here. But you've lost everything you needed to get through.

content.text:
You turn back. It's not cowardice - it's survival. The water is rising too fast. You'd drown before reaching the grate.

You fight against the current, pulling yourself back toward the junction. The water follows you, rising, but you're faster moving upstream.

You reach the three-way junction just as the drainage tunnel floods completely behind you. That was close. Too close.

You're back where you started. Wet. Cold. But alive.

Time to reconsider your options.

pages:
Thirty minutes. You can do this.

You move fast, splashing through the rising water. The drainage tunnel slopes downward. The water is ankle-deep, then knee-deep, but the current is manageable. Yet.

Fifteen minutes. The water is waist-deep. You can see the tide markers on the walls rising past you. The ocean is coming in.

Ten minutes. Chest-deep. The current pulls harder. Your progress slows.

Five minutes. You can see the grate ahead. Moonlight. Freedom. But the water is at your shoulders now, and rising.

You have maybe three minutes of air left before this tunnel becomes a death trap.

Patience. Patience is what separates the living from the dead down here.

You find a side chamber - one of the old storage rooms you discovered during scouting. High enough that the tide won't reach it. You settle in to wait.

Hours pass. You hear the water rising in the main tunnel, filling the passages, flooding the drainage route completely. You made the right choice.

Eventually, the sound changes. The water stops rising. Begins to recede. The tide is turning.

You wait until you hear the dripping slow. Until the echo of flowing water fades to a trickle. Then you emerge.

The drainage tunnel is passable now. Low tide. Safe passage.

But the prison above will be waking soon. Dawn is coming. Your window is closing.

content.text:
You study the junction again. Three routes. You chose the drainage route, but the other two are still there.

The narrow passage to the left - the crack you could barely squeeze through during scouting. It led to ancient tunnels, away from the ocean. Not an escape route... or is it?

The right passage - the one that led up toward the guard area, the vertical shaft. Dangerous, but it avoided the water entirely.

Maybe the drainage route isn't the only way. Maybe there's an alternative you haven't considered.

pages: The ocean grate is iron. Old. Rusted from decades of salt water. Strong enough to keep prisoners in, but maybe not strong enough to keep a desperate engineer out.
You examine it in the faint moonlight. The bars are thick, but the mortar holding them in place is crumbling. Years of tidal pressure have weakened the foundation.

You have your knife - if you didn't lose it. You have your strength. You have minutes before the water rises to cover the air pocket completely.

Time to work.

content.text:
You cling to the grate, gasping for air. Your tools are gone. Your map is destroyed. You have nothing but your bare hands.

You try to pull the bars loose. They don't budge. You try to dig at the mortar with your fingers. It crumbles, but too slowly. You need hours, and you have minutes.

The water rises. The air pocket shrinks. Your last breaths count down.

This is how it ends. Not in the prison. Not in a cell. But here, in the dark, so close to freedom you can taste the salt air.

You failed.

You're back at the three-way junction. Wet. Frustrated. But not defeated.

The drainage route failed. But you still have options:

The narrow passage to the left - the ancient tunnels. Unknown. Unexplored beyond your initial scouting. But dry.

The right passage - leading up toward the guard area. Dangerous. But it avoids the water.

Or you could return to your cell. Wait for another night. Plan better. Time the tides.

choices.text: Try the ancient tunnel route instead
Try the vertical shaft route instead
Return to your cell - try again another night

content.text:
The drainage tunnel at low tide is exactly as you mapped it. Water trickling along the channel. Walls slick with algae. The smell of salt and stone.

You move quickly but carefully. Your footsteps splash quietly through shallow puddles. The ocean grate is ahead - you can hear the waves beyond it.

No time pressure now. No racing current. Just you, your tools, and the barrier between imprisonment and freedom.

You reach the grate as the first grey light of dawn begins to filter through. You have maybe an hour before the prison wakes. Before your absence is discovered.

Time to work.

You choose a different path. The drainage route proved too dangerous, too unpredictable. But you're an engineer - adaptability is survival.

The alternative route stretches before you. Unknown. Challenging. But perhaps it leads somewhere the drainage tunnel never could.

Sometimes the path to freedom isn't the one you planned. Sometimes it's the one you discover when your first plan fails.

pages: The grate. The final barrier. Between you and the Atlantic Ocean. Between imprisonment and escape.
You work the knife into the mortar. Chip. Scrape. Pry. The old mortar crumbles. Decades of salt water have done most of the work - you're just finishing what the ocean started.

One bar loosens. Then another. You can squeeze through now - barely. The ocean beckons. Cold. Dark. Free.

This is it. The moment you've been planning for. The moment that will define everything that comes after.

Do you take it?

NIGHT 29

Two nights since you discovered the vertical shaft during your scouting mission. Two nights of studying the guard rotations near the lighthouse. Two nights of planning.
The shaft leads up, not out. But up means access to the guard levels. The armory. The communications room. And most importantly - the lighthouse itself.

The lighthouse sits on the highest point of the island. Every night, its beam sweeps across the Atlantic, warning ships away from the rocks.

But what if that beam could send a different message? What if someone was watching?

content.text:
But first, you need information. The guard schedules. The lighthouse keeper's routines. Access codes if there are any.

You have three potential sources:

Bastian might know something. He's been here longer than you, and he's observant. But sharing your plan means trusting him completely.

Ã‰mile Beaumont's network definitely knows. But his information comes with a price - and obligations you might not want.

Or you could observe and gather intelligence yourself. Slower. Riskier. But it keeps the plan entirely in your control.

Deal with Ã‰mile - get professional intel
Gather intelligence yourself - stay independent

pages:
That night, after lights out, you tell Bastian everything.

The vertical shaft. The lighthouse plan. Your engineering calculations about signal distances and boat response times.

He listens without interrupting. When you finish, he's quiet for a long moment.

"You're serious," he finally says. Not a question. An observation.

"There's someone," Bastian continues slowly. "A woman. Cordelia Beaumont - Ã‰mile's cousin, ironically. She runs a fishing boat along the coast. She's helped prisoners before. For the right price."

He pauses. "I can get a message to her. But Alexandre... if this fails, if we're caught, they'll put us in isolation. Or worse."
You find Ã‰mile in the yard during exercise hour. He's surrounded by his people, as always. Watching. Calculating.

"I need information," you tell him directly. "Guard schedules for the lighthouse. Keeper routines. Access patterns."

Ã‰mile studies you with cold eyes. "And what does an engineer want with the lighthouse?"

You don't answer. He doesn't need to know your plan.

"Information costs," Ã‰mile says. "You want my network's intelligence? You work for me. Three jobs. Whatever I need. Structural assessments, electrical work, lock picking."

He leans closer. "And if you're planning what I think you're planning... I want 20% of whatever money you're hiding on the outside."

content.text:
You spend five nights watching. Observing. Learning.

The lighthouse keeper - an old guard named Marcel - follows a precise routine. Up the stairs at 1900 hours. Maintenance check at 2200 hours. Down at 0600 hours.

But there's a gap. Every third night, Marcel descends at 0200 hours to refill the fuel reservoir from the ground-level storage. Twenty minutes. Alone. Vulnerable.

The shaft you discovered leads to a maintenance corridor that connects to the lighthouse base. If you could reach it during Marcel's fuel run, you'd have access to the tower.

"Can you really get a message to Cordelia?" you ask.

Bastian nods. "Father Michel. The chaplain. He delivers letters to the mainland sometimes - officially for family contact, unofficially for... other purposes."

"Cordelia won't come for free," Bastian warns. "She'll want 500 francs. Cash. Waiting for her at a dead drop location."

500 francs. You don't have that kind of money. But maybe you could promise it. Or find another way to convince her.

choices.text: Promise Cordelia the money - deal with it later
Offer Cordelia information instead - leverage what you know
Ask Bastian to come with you - split the cost

content.text:
Ã‰mile's terms are harsh. But his intelligence is reliable.

"Fine," you say. "Three jobs. But I want the information first."

Ã‰mile smiles. Not warmly. "You'll get your information when I get my first job completed. There's a storage room in the west wing. The lock is broken but the guards don't know. I need you to map the electrical conduits - I'm planning something."

He hands you a small piece of paper. "Guard schedules. Lighthouse access. Everything you need. But remember, engineer - you owe me now."

choices.text: Accept Ã‰mile's terms - you need the intel
Refuse the deal - find another way

content.text:
Your observations have paid off. You know Marcel's routine. You know the timing window. You know the route.

But you're alone. No backup. No external contact. If something goes wrong, there's no one to help.

The lighthouse has signal equipment - the beam itself, plus emergency flares for maritime distress. If you could send a signal, ships might respond. But you'd need to know what signal to send. And you'd need someone willing to pick up an escaped prisoner.

This route is possible. But it's dangerous. More dangerous than the drainage route, perhaps. Because it relies entirely on hope - hope that someone will see your signal and respond.

"I'll get her the money," you lie. "There's a deposit box. Family funds. I can access it once I'm free."

Bastian looks skeptical but doesn't challenge you. He writes the message carefully: coordinates, timing, signal pattern.

Father Michel accepts the letter without questions. He's done this before.

Three days later, Bastian receives a reply. A single word, scratched on the back of a prayer card: "OUI."

Cordelia will be waiting. Off the northwest coast. Watching for your signal.

Now you just need to reach the lighthouse and send it.

"I can't pay cash," you admit. "But I know things. About Marchand. About the train crash conspiracy. Information that could be valuable to the right people."

Bastian considers this. Then he writes a different letter.

Father Michel delivers it. The response takes a week.

When it comes, it's longer than before. Cordelia wants specifics. Names. Dates. Evidence.

"She's interested," Bastian translates. "But she wants proof you're not bluffing. Can you provide documentation?"

You think about the papers you've memorized. The testimony you could give. It might be enough.

pages:
"Come with me," you say. "We split the cost. Split the risk. Two men have a better chance than one."

Bastian goes very still. You see something in his eyes - hope? Fear? Both?

"I've been in here for eight years," he says quietly. "Eight years of watching men try to escape. Most of them die. The ones who don't... they get caught within days."

He looks at you. Really looks at you.

"But you're different. You actually have a plan. Engineering. Precision." He takes a breath. "Yes. I'll come. And I'll handle Cordelia's payment. I have... resources. People on the outside."

Your cellmate is now your partner. The escape is no longer a solo mission.

content.text:
You take Ã‰mile's paper. The information is detailed - guard names, shift changes, access codes.

The lighthouse keeper, Marcel, follows a precise schedule. Every third night, he descends at 0200 hours for fuel. Twenty-minute window.

But Ã‰mile's intelligence comes with strings attached. You owe him three jobs. And 20% of money you don't have.

You'll deal with that later. For now, you have what you need to reach the lighthouse.

The question is: what happens when you get there?

"No deal," you say. "I don't owe you anything."

Ã‰mile's expression doesn't change, but his eyes go cold.

"Everyone owes someone in here, engineer. You'll learn that."

He walks away. His people close ranks around him.

You're on your own now. No Ã‰mile. No intelligence network. Just you and whatever you can observe yourself.

It's going to be harder. Much harder. But at least you won't be in debt to a criminal.

NIGHT 35

The third night of Marcel's fuel run cycle. Your window.

You've mapped the route: chapel basement, through the catacombs, up the vertical shaft, through the maintenance corridor, into the lighthouse base.

You have your tools. You have your timing. You have your plan.

But you don't have a boat. You don't have outside contact. If you send a signal, you're hoping - praying - that someone sees it and responds.

It's a gamble. The biggest gamble of your life.

Cordelia's boat will be offshore. Waiting. Watching for your signal.

Cordelia is expecting you. The question is: can you reach the lighthouse?

Bastian is slower than you - older, less fit. But he's determined. Eight years of imprisonment have given him something you don't have yet: absolute commitment to freedom.

You return to your cell before anyone notices you're gone. Bastian stirs as you climb into your bunk.

"Couldn't do it?" he asks quietly.

"Not tonight," you reply.
