pages:
The loading dock is chaos. Guards shouting. Searchlights sweeping. The supply boat rocking against the pier.

You gripped the sharpened spoon in your hand - a pathetic weapon against rifles. But you were desperate. Cornered.

"Drop it!" the guard captain shouted.

You lunged forward instead.

The gunshots were deafening. Three. Four. Five.

You don't feel the bullets at first. Just the impact. The force throwing you backward.

Then you're falling. The cold Atlantic water rushes up to meet you. The last thing you see is the fortress walls, towering above. Still a prisoner. Forever.

DEATH ENDING

SHOT AT THE DOCK

You died attempting to fight armed guards at the loading dock. The sea claimed your body. No one will remember your name.

Sometimes courage is not enough. Sometimes the system is too strong. Sometimes rebellion ends in cold water and silence.

Your conspiracy against Francois Marchand dies with you. He will never face justice.

THE END

The tunnel is flooding faster than you calculated. The water is already at your chest. Your waist. Your neck.

You miscalculated the tide. Or the drainage rate. Or both. Engineer's hubris. You thought you could predict nature.

The ceiling is three inches from the waterline now. Two inches. One.

You press your face against the rough stone, gasping for the last pockets of air. The water tastes of salt and rust and centuries of darkness.

No air left. Only water. Your lungs burn. Your vision darkens at the edges.

You think of Sophie. The train. Forty-seven dead. Now forty-eight.

DEATH ENDING

DROWNED UNDERGROUND

You died in the flooded catacombs beneath ÃŽle de Pierre. Your body will never be found. The tide will carry your bones through ancient tunnels, deep into the bedrock.

The prisoners above will notice you're missing at morning count. The guards will search for a week. Then you'll be listed as escaped. An unsolved mystery.

Francois Marchand will read about your disappearance in the newspaper. He will smile.

THE END

The boat is sinking. You felt it take on water an hour ago - a slow leak, growing steadily worse. Now it's undeniable.

The Atlantic stretches in every direction. Black water. Black sky. No lights. No land. No rescue.

You tried to bail. You tried to patch the leak. But the boat is old, the wood rotten, and the sea is merciless.

The water is at your knees now. Then your waist. The boat lists heavily to starboard.

You slide into the ocean. The cold is shocking. Paralyzing. You try to swim, but hypothermia is already setting in. Your limbs feel heavy. Distant.

You float on your back, looking up at the stars. They're beautiful. You haven't seen stars in months.

Your eyes close. The sea is actually quite peaceful, you think. Quite gentle.

The Atlantic has claimed thousands of bodies. What's one more?

DEATH ENDING

LOST AT SEA

You died of exposure and drowning in the Atlantic Ocean, miles from shore. Your body will wash up on a beach in Cornwall three weeks later, unidentifiable.

The prison will report you as escaped. Technically true. You did escape the fortress.

But freedom was only a brief, cold dream.

THE END

The rope is fraying. You can feel it. Each fiber snapping, one by one. The lighthouse is a hundred feet tall. You're halfway down.

You should have checked the rope more carefully. Should have tested it. Should have been more methodical.

The rope jerks. A sickening lurch. More fibers breaking.

You try to grip the stone wall, find a handhold, slow your descent. But the lighthouse exterior is smooth, weathered by centuries of Atlantic wind.

The rope snaps.

For a moment, you're weightless. Falling through the darkness. The stars above. The rocks below.

SNAP.

DEATH ENDING

FALL FROM LIGHTHOUSE

You died falling from the prison lighthouse. Your body struck the rocks at the base with fatal force. Death was instantaneous.

A guard patrol found you at dawn. They assumed you climbed the lighthouse to attempt suicide. Another prisoner broken by the system. They've seen it before.

You'll be buried in the prison cemetery on the northeast corner of the island. No marker. No name. Just a number.

Francois Marchand will never know how close you came to exposing him.

THE END

Chef Pierre stands in the doorway, arms crossed. His eyes are cold. Behind him: three guards.

"I knew something was wrong," Pierre says quietly. "Too many questions about the loading dock. Too much interest in the guard rotations. I've been running this kitchen for fifteen years, Alexandre. I know when someone's planning something."

The guards move fast. Professional. Efficient. They drag you from the kitchen before you can even think about resistance.

You see the other inmates watching. Some look sympathetic. Most look relieved it wasn't them.

The hole. That's what they call it. Solitary confinement in the basement levels. No light. No sound. Just stone walls and your own thoughts.

The Warden visits on the third day. Or maybe the fourth. Time has no meaning in the darkness.

"Twenty more years added to your sentence," he says. "Attempted escape. Theft of prison property. Conspiracy."

He pauses at the door. "You should have just served your time, Dubois. Now you'll die here. In the dark."

CAPTURE ENDING

CAUGHT IN KITCHEN

Your escape attempt failed before it truly began. Pierre's vigilance, the prison's security, and your own impatience conspired against you.

You'll spend the next three months in solitary. When you emerge, every guard will know your face. Every privilege will be revoked. The other prisoners will avoid you - association with an escape attempt brings scrutiny.

ÃŽle de Pierre has crushed better men than you. The fortress never lets go.

Francois Marchand will never face justice. You'll die forgotten in this place.

THE END

The searchlight finds you halfway to the boat.

You freeze. Every instinct screams RUN, but there's nowhere to go. The loading dock is open ground. The boat is fifty feet away. The searchlight pins you like an insect.

"DON'T MOVE!"

Guards pour from three directions. You counted their patrol patterns. You timed the gaps. But you missed something. A fourth guard. A backup rotation. One small miscalculation.

They don't go easy on you. The first guard's rifle butt catches you in the stomach. You go down hard on the stone dock. Then the boots start.

You curl up, trying to protect your head and ribs. It doesn't matter. They're professionals. They know how to hurt you without leaving permanent damage.

Three weeks in the infirmary. Two cracked ribs. Concussion. Bruises that paint your entire torso purple and black.

Then six months in solitary confinement.

The Warden makes an example of you at morning assembly when you finally emerge. "This is what happens to those who try to leave us," he announces to five hundred prisoners.

CAPTURE ENDING

CAUGHT AT DOCK

You came so close. Fifty feet from the boat. Fifty feet from freedom. But the prison's security proved stronger than your planning.

The beating has left you with a permanent limp. Your left eye doesn't focus quite right anymore. And every prisoner knows your face as "the engineer who tried and failed."

Your reputation for planning and intelligence is destroyed. No one will trust you with another escape plan. You're a marked man.

ÃŽle de Pierre keeps its prisoners. Always.

THE END

You've been in the boat for three hours. The island is a dark shadow behind you. The coast of France is somewhere ahead in the darkness.

Then you see the light. Not a lighthouse. Not a fishing boat. A spotlight. Powerful. Sweeping. Military.

The coast guard cutter cuts through the waves like a knife. Fast. Unstoppable.

"HEAVE TO! KILL YOUR ENGINE!"

You consider running. But where? They're faster. Better equipped. You have a stolen fishing boat with a sputtering motor. They have a patrol vessel designed for exactly this scenario.

They haul you aboard like cargo. Rough hands. Metal cuffs. No words. Just professional efficiency.

The captain looks at you with something like pity. "ÃŽle de Pierre?" he asks. You nod. He sighs. "They always try. They never make it."

The return to the island is worse than the original arrival. You know what's waiting.

The Warden stands on the dock, hands behind his back, watching as they drag you off the coast guard vessel. He doesn't look angry. He looks satisfied.

"Welcome back, Dubois," he says. "We've prepared your new accommodations. I think you'll find them... memorable."

CAPTURE ENDING

CAUGHT AT SEA

You tasted freedom for three hours. You felt the wind and saw the stars. You almost made it.

Almost doesn't matter.

One year in solitary confinement. Then transfer to the maximum security block. No more work assignments. No more privileges. Twenty-three hours a day in a cell measuring six feet by eight feet.

The other prisoners will hear the story. "The engineer who got caught at sea." A cautionary tale. A reminder that the fortress never lets go.

Francois Marchand will read about your recapture in the newspaper. He will sleep well knowing the truth died with your freedom.

THE END

You wake to sunlight. Real sunlight, not filtered through prison bars. The rocking motion has stopped.

You're in the back of the supply truck, hidden among crates of vegetables and flour sacks. The engine is silent. You hear voices outside - dock workers, casual conversation, not the clipped commands of guards.

You peek through a gap in the canvas. A port. Marseille, maybe? Or Brest? You're not sure. But you're on the mainland. You're off the island.

You wait until the voices fade, then slip out the back of the truck. No alarms. No shouts. Just morning workers going about their day.

You walk. One foot in front of the other. Trying to look casual. Trying not to run. Every person you pass could recognize you from newspapers. Every policeman could be looking for escapees.

But no one stops you. No one even looks twice.

You're just another dock worker. Another tired face in the morning crowd.

ESCAPE ENDING

THE SUPPLY TRUCK

You escaped ÃŽle de Pierre hidden in a supply truck. Simple. Practical. The engineer's solution.

No dramatic boat chase. No gunfight. No heroic last stand. You hid among vegetables and rode to freedom.

Now comes the hard part: staying free. Building a new identity. Finding evidence to expose Francois Marchand. Bringing justice for Sophie and the forty-seven dead.

The prison is behind you. But the fight for truth has just begun.

You are Alexandre Dubois. You are an engineer. You are wrongfully convicted.

And you are free.

THE END

The fishing boat cuts through the early morning waves. Behind you, ÃŽle de Pierre is a dark smudge on the horizon. Growing smaller. Disappearing.

You stole this boat from the loading dock. Cut the mooring lines. Started the engine. Left before anyone realized what you were doing.

The fuel gauge shows half a tank. Maybe enough to reach the coast. Maybe not. You don't have charts. Don't know the currents. Don't know which direction is safest.

You're an engineer, not a sailor. But you're free. That's what matters.

The sun rises. Golden light spreads across the Atlantic. You see the French coast ahead - rocky cliffs, small villages, church steeples.

You beach the boat in a small cove. No one sees you. You climb the rocks, soaking wet, exhausted, but alive.

ESCAPE ENDING

THE STOLEN BOAT

You escaped ÃŽle de Pierre by stealing a fishing boat. Bold. Dangerous. Desperate.

You could have drowned. Could have been caught. Could have run out of fuel and drifted back to the island. But you didn't.

Now you stand on French soil, a fugitive with no money, no identity papers, no allies. Just the clothes on your back and the knowledge that Francois Marchand must face justice.

The boat theft will make headlines. Your face will be in every newspaper. Finding you will be a priority.

But you're free. And for now, that's enough.

THE END

You crawl onto the beach, coughing seawater. Your lungs burn. Your muscles scream. You've been swimming for what feels like hours.

The tunnel exit was exactly where the map said it would be. But the tide was wrong. Or your timing was off. Or both. The water nearly killed you.

You lie on the rocky shore, gasping. Above you: stars. Real stars. Not seen through prison bars. The sound of waves. The smell of salt and seaweed and freedom.

You almost didn't make it. Three times you thought about turning back. Three times you pushed forward anyway.

You check yourself. Cuts and bruises. Hypothermia setting in. Exhausted beyond measure. But alive. Impossibly, incredibly alive.

You stand on shaking legs. The prison is somewhere behind you, across black water. You don't look back.

ESCAPE ENDING

THE NARROW ESCAPE

You escaped ÃŽle de Pierre through the smuggler tunnels. Barely.

You survived by luck as much as planning. The water nearly drowned you. The cold nearly killed you. But you kept swimming. Kept pushing. Kept fighting.

Engineers calculate risks. You calculated this one and went anyway, knowing the odds were against you.

Now you're free, but marked by the experience. You'll have nightmares of drowning in darkness. You'll flinch at enclosed spaces. The tunnels left scars you can't see.

But you're free. And that's worth everything.

THE END

You're free. You made it off the island. You're standing on a quiet street in a coastal town, watching the sunrise.

But your hands won't stop shaking.

The guard at the loading dock. You didn't mean to kill him. You just needed him to stop, to be quiet, to let you pass. But he reached for his whistle, and you had the sharpened spoon, andâ€”

It happened so fast. One moment he was standing. The next he was on the ground, blood spreading across the stones, eyes wide and confused and accusing.

You didn't stop to check if he was dead. You just ran.

But you know. You felt the blade go in. You heard him fall. You saw the blood.

Forty-seven people died because of Francois Marchand's greed. You were wrongfully convicted for their deaths. And now you've added one more death to the count.

A guard. Just doing his job. Maybe he had a family. Maybe he had children. You'll never know.

ESCAPE ENDING

BLOOD ON YOUR HANDS

You escaped ÃŽle de Pierre. But the price was a man's life.

You told yourself it was self-defense. Survival. Necessary. But late at night, when you close your eyes, you see his face. The surprise. The pain. The accusation.

You wanted to prove your innocence. To expose Marchand. To get justice for Sophie and the forty-seven dead.

But now you're not innocent anymore. Now you're guilty of exactly what you were convicted of: causing death through your actions.

You're free. But you'll never be free of this.

THE END

The fisherman found you at dawn, clinging to wreckage from the boat. You were barely conscious. Hypothermic. Minutes from death.

He pulled you aboard without a word. Wrapped you in blankets. Gave you hot coffee. Didn't ask questions.

"ÃŽle de Pierre?" he finally asks, once you can speak.

You nod. Waiting for him to turn the boat around. To radio the coast guard. To collect the reward money.

Instead, he nods. "My brother was there. Ten years. Said he was innocent too." He pauses. "He died in that place. 1919. Tuberculosis."

The fisherman takes you to a small village. Gives you clothes, money, papers with a new name. "My brother's identity," he says. "He won't be needing it."

You try to thank him. He waves it away. "Just... don't waste it. The freedom. My brother never got his. You make it count."

ESCAPE ENDING

THE FISHERMAN'S MERCY

You escaped ÃŽle de Pierre through the kindness of a stranger.

Jean-Baptiste Laurent. A fisherman who lost his brother to the prison system. A quiet man who saw you dying in the water and chose mercy over reward.

He gave you his brother's identity. A new name. A second chance.

You can never repay him. Can never find him again - he made sure of that. But you can honor his gift. Make your freedom matter. Expose Marchand. Get justice for Sophie.

You escaped with your life and your conscience intact. The fisherman saved both.

THE END

The smugglers found you in their tunnels. You expected them to kill you. Or turn you in. Instead, they laughed.

"Another one from the fortress," the leader said. "You're the third this year. The tunnels always find the desperate ones."

They offered you a choice: join them, or take your chances alone in the dark. You chose the smugglers.

They got you off the island. Gave you clothes, papers, money. But nothing is free. Now you work for them. Running contraband. Bribing officials. Doing things you swore you'd never do.

You're free, but trapped in a different kind of prison. The smuggler network has its own rules. Its own hierarchy. Its own punishments for those who betray it.

Sophie's face is starting to fade from your memory. The train crash feels like someone else's tragedy. Francois Marchand seems very far away.

ESCAPE ENDING

THE SMUGGLER NETWORK

You escaped ÃŽle de Pierre by joining the criminals who use its tunnels.

You're free from the prison. But you've traded one cage for another. The smugglers own you now. You move their goods, do their jobs, keep their secrets.

You wanted to prove your innocence. To get justice. To honor Sophie's memory. Instead, you've become exactly what they accused you of being: a criminal.

Sometimes, late at night, you think about walking away. Finding Marchand. Exposing the truth. But the smugglers made it clear: once you're in the network, you're in for life.

At least you're not in a cell. That's something. Isn't it?

THE END

The boat appears exactly when Bastian said it would. Every Thursday at 3 AM, his sister Cordelia passes close to the northwest rocks. "If she sees the lighthouse signal," he told you, "she'll come."

You climbed the lighthouse. Sent the signal. Three long, two short, three long. The code Bastian taught you.

Now you're on her boat, wrapped in blankets, drinking hot soup. Cordelia looks like her brother - same sharp eyes, same quiet competence.

"Bastian talked about you in his letters," she says. "Said you were smart. Kind. That you deserved better than that place." She pauses. "He made me promise to watch for the signal. Every Thursday. For as long as it took."

You ask about getting Bastian out too. Cordelia shakes her head sadly. "He won't leave. He's got other plans. But he wanted you to make it. Said you could actually prove your innocence. That you could do something with your freedom."

She hands you an envelope. "He wanted you to have this." Inside: documents. Names. Evidence. Things Bastian collected over years. Things that point to Marchand.

ESCAPE ENDING

BASTIAN'S SISTER

You escaped ÃŽle de Pierre with help from your cellmate's sister.

Bastian Laurent spent years planning your escape, not his own. He trusted you with his sister's life. Gave you his evidence. Sacrificed his own chance at freedom to ensure yours.

You owe him everything. And he'll never leave that prison.

Cordelia takes you to a safe house. Gives you money, papers, contacts. "My brother believes in you," she says. "Don't waste it. Get the truth out there. Make his faith worth something."

You have the evidence. You have your freedom. You have allies.

Now you have to finish what you started. For Sophie. For Bastian. For the truth.

This is the best way out of the fortress. You didn't do it alone.

THE END

You walk out the front gate at 6:47 AM, during the guard shift change. Timing perfect. Uniform perfect. Forged papers perfect.

The guard at the gate barely glances at your transfer documents. "Another reassignment to the mainland? Third one this month."

You nod, say nothing. Keep your face neutral. Keep your breathing steady.

He waves you through. Just like that. The gate opens. You walk across the causeway to the dock. Board the supply boat with the other guards rotating off duty. Sit in the back. Don't make eye contact.

No alarms. No chase. No dramatic escape. You're a ghost. A clerical error. A man who was never really there.

The prison doesn't realize you're gone until evening count. By then you're three hundred miles away, your guard uniform burned, your face clean-shaven, your gait changed. Alexandre Dubois the prisoner no longer exists.

They'll search for weeks. Investigate the guards. Question everyone. But they'll never understand how you did it.

ESCAPE ENDING

THE FRONT DOOR

You escaped ÃŽle de Pierre by walking out the front gate in a guard uniform.

The hardest escape. The most audacious. Perfect timing. Perfect disguise. Perfect nerve.

You spent months memorizing guard schedules, forging documents, stealing uniform pieces one at a time. Any mistake would have meant death or solitary confinement.

But there were no mistakes. You're an engineer. Engineers don't leave variables to chance.

You're free, and they don't even know you're gone yet. You have a head start. Resources. Time.

Time to find Marchand. Time to gather evidence. Time to prove your innocence and expose the truth about Sophie's death and the forty-seven lives lost.

You walked out of hell like you owned the place.

Now make it count.

THE END
